story:
What We Need & What You Get

 

We are seeking 20,000 dollars this will cover all 68 (COMPLETED) pages of the book.

This also pays for the 2 covers (COMPLETED) an optional poster(COMPLETED)       

If the entire goal isn't reached what is contributed will go to printing what is needed and if              the goal isn't reached no more chapter can come.

However WHEN the goal is reached not only will the funds go to printing and distribution of          the comic we will start on the next chapter. 

The whole first issue is ready (ALL 68 page) to go to print  

        ​

The Impact

 

      This project has been in my head since at least 2013 I began making it a reality in January of 2015 after meeting Jeff Hick at the 2014 Cincinnati Comic Expo. Many twist and turns came over time Jeff went on to do his own thing and I thought this may never get finished. That changed when I met Nick Crook. Nick brought the project to completion ( of ACT 1).     

As a contributor you will be changing my whole world. By bringing the world I've envisioned for so long into being and this first 68 page story is only the beginning. 

Short Summary

 

Fear is what keeps good men from being great men. We’ve all faced a situation where we saw someone who needed our help, and yet we did nothing because of our biological imperative for self-preservation. Our heart knows what’s right - our brain knows what’s smart, and ultimately the brain wins out every time death is a possibility. But what if death was no longer a factor? Would we then always do what was right, now that we’re free from mortal consequence?

Everlasting Survivors explores these questions, among other topics not yet fully examined by the comic book medium. The book follows three heroes, all of whom possess an eclectic assortment of powers, with one unifying characteristic; if they die, they will resurrect with even more abilities than before. Death, then, has become something not to fear, but rather something to look forward to.

When we’re first introduced to the characters, they have yet to understand how they got their powers and what these new powers mean for mankind’s future. As the story unfolds, our heroes search for these answers while coming face-to-face with even bigger questions, like: What does sacrifice mean when you have nothing to lose?

Overview

 

Our heroes are Dominic Kanuho, Reece Shaw and Faviana “Ana” Maldonado. Dominic and Reece both fully embrace the limelight that their newfound powers have provided them, and with the help of an image consulting firm (ran by Reece and Ana’s sister Marie), use their powers for both the good of the people and for the adoration of their fans. Ana is different. She wears a mask and uses a code name - Sublime Eye - so that she can still be a nurse in her everyday life without being inundated by the fame that comes with her alter ego.

Their world is much like ours; pessimistic, cynical, seemingly hopeless, cruel and confusing and filled with lies, deceit, malice and greed. The inhabitants of this world need a savior, whether they realize it or not. Are these heroes ready to answer that unspoken call?

​

 

Risks & Challenges

 

       I got the largest obstacles out of the way all art has been COMPLETED.

       The biggest risk we face is NOT getting the printing cost covered.

       The team is working hard to face the challenge of getting the word out about this.

       Addition risk comes from shipping anything can happen especially in a COVID world.   

    

Other Ways You Can Help

 

        If you're here and unable to contribute you can still help!

        Maybe someone you know would like to contribute and they haven't heard about us yet.

        Use the Indiegogo share tools!

        Get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.

And that's all there is to it.
story_txt:
What We Need & What You Get
 
We are seeking 20,000 dollars this will cover all 68 (COMPLETED) pages of the book.
This also pays for the 2 covers (COMPLETED) an optional poster(COMPLETED)       
If the entire goal isn't reached what is contributed will go to printing what is needed and if              the goal isn't reached no more chapter can come.
However WHEN the goal is reached not only will the funds go to printing and distribution of          the comic we will start on the next chapter. 
The whole first issue is ready (ALL 68 page) to go to print  
        ​


The Impact
 
      This project has been in my head since at least 2013 I began making it a reality in January of 2015 after meeting Jeff Hick at the 2014 Cincinnati Comic Expo. Many twist and turns came over time Jeff went on to do his own thing and I thought this may never get finished. That changed when I met Nick Crook. Nick brought the project to completion ( of ACT 1).     
As a contributor you will be changing my whole world. By bringing the world I've envisioned for so long into being and this first 68 page story is only the beginning. 

Short Summary
 
Fear is what keeps good men from being great men. We’ve all faced a situation where we saw someone who needed our help, and yet we did nothing because of our biological imperative for self-preservation. Our heart knows what’s right - our brain knows what’s smart, and ultimately the brain wins out every time death is a possibility. But what if death was no longer a factor? Would we then always do what was right, now that we’re free from mortal consequence?
Everlasting Survivors explores these questions, among other topics not yet fully examined by the comic book medium. The book follows three heroes, all of whom possess an eclectic assortment of powers, with one unifying characteristic; if they die, they will resurrect with even more abilities than before. Death, then, has become something not to fear, but rather something to look forward to.
When we’re first introduced to the characters, they have yet to understand how they got their powers and what these new powers mean for mankind’s future. As the story unfolds, our heroes search for these answers while coming face-to-face with even bigger questions, like: What does sacrifice mean when you have nothing to lose?





Overview
 
Our heroes are Dominic Kanuho, Reece Shaw and Faviana “Ana” Maldonado. Dominic and Reece both fully embrace the limelight that their newfound powers have provided them, and with the help of an image consulting firm (ran by Reece and Ana’s sister Marie), use their powers for both the good of the people and for the adoration of their fans. Ana is different. She wears a mask and uses a code name - Sublime Eye - so that she can still be a nurse in her everyday life without being inundated by the fame that comes with her alter ego.
Their world is much like ours; pessimistic, cynical, seemingly hopeless, cruel and confusing and filled with lies, deceit, malice and greed. The inhabitants of this world need a savior, whether they realize it or not. Are these heroes ready to answer that unspoken call?
​



 

Risks & Challenges
 
       I got the largest obstacles out of the way all art has been COMPLETED.
       The biggest risk we face is NOT getting the printing cost covered.
       The team is working hard to face the challenge of getting the word out about this.
       Addition risk comes from shipping anything can happen especially in a COVID world.   
    

Other Ways You Can Help
 
        If you're here and unable to contribute you can still help!
        Maybe someone you know would like to contribute and they haven't heard about us yet.
        Use the Indiegogo share tools!
        Get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
And that's all there is to it.

story:
We are raising funds to publish a historical graphic novel about the Early Middle Ages, when emperors of the Holy Roman Empire of German Nations ruled the territory of Central Europe. The surrounding duchies and kingdoms faced a stark choice: to serve the Emperor and live in peace, or to fight for independence.

We own the recipe (not as well-kept as Coca Cola’s) to defeat the boredom elicited by old history books:  

1. by finding the most interesting, albeit almost forgotten or even barely known historical events; battles, treason, regicide, massacre..

2. adding new aspects with imaginary, but trendy characters; Vikings (Varangian bodyguards), Alsatian assassins, cunning archbishops...

3. and finally shaking (but not stirring!) and then introducing them in an artistic graphic novel.  

Our contributors will receive a fancy looking book of 100 pages, with a hard cover, in full color, of 8.5 x 11 inches (280 x 216 mm) printed on quality paper. But of course this is the least we could do, isn’t it?  

But there is something even more fancy you can expect! Through a smartphone android application historical location (Ruprechtskirche in Vienna), interesting characters (German knights, Hungarian light horse archers) and additional contents can be viewed in Augmented Reality to give you a better feel for the story.

We are just a small – but very enthusiastic - Central European creative team behind this project, so we are looking for contributors who will help us to break into the international markets. Our book will make its official debut at the Vienna Comiccon, on 18-19th November, 2017, in Vienna, Austria.

1030 AD, somewhere in the accursed marshes along the River Danube, deep in the heart of Europe.  

The Emperor’s cavalry is completely bogged down in the mud. “Isn’t it better than snow?” they ask themselves, a perfect example of famous last words before disaster strikes.  

Our story starts with an invasion by the allied armies of Conrad II, Holy Roman Emperor of the territory occupied by the “old enemy”, the increasingly troublesome, half-pagan and aggressively expansionist Kingdom of Hungary. The aging Hungarian king, Stephen I, sends his only remaining son, and heir to throne, to fight the invaders. Who will come out the victor? The well-trained, heavy cavalry of the Germans or the mixed battalions of fierce Hungarian horsemen, backed by fancy-looking, yet not the most reliable Italian cavaliers. The odds are against the Hungarians, but they are on their home turf. And this turf is muddy, swampy, and could be extremely dangerous for courageous though arrogant knights weighed down by their armour. 

Some of our characters will be familiar to the fans of knights’ tales and those who love European history: German emperors and princes, Austrian margraves, Czech princes, Hungarian warlords, and pagan tribesmen. But the most interesting characters are fictitious: an Alsatian mercenary hunting for the heir to the thrones, Viking bodyguards fighting alongside with mounted nomad horsemen, cunning highly placed priests always rebelling against their kings, etc.  

Did you know that in the 11th century employing a Viking (a so-called Varangian) bodyguard was a fashionable way of avoiding regicide? Assuming of course you were a hated king/prince or anything similar with more than enough enemies.

We invested a lot of time in researching our characters’ genealogies and even more time depicting them. SPOILER ALERT! Sean Bean isn’t among our characters, so please DO NOT EXPECT them all to be killed off at the end of part I. Of course, popular demand might make us reconsider and approach his agent. We are sure that our stories are sometimes as interesting as those in Game of Thrones, but in our case you don’t have to wait a week for the next episode. Our book includes some interesting facts such as:  

• what’s the difference between a Pecheneg and a Hiptschak (as if anybody cares…)

• what’s behind the common misbelief that a Hungarian heir to the throne would make a pledge to remain a virgin for life

• how to evade a storm of Hungarian arrows (Run, you fools!)

• how to behave with people coming from exotic Eastern countries in a constant state of civil war (this could be extremely useful if you accidentally find yourself on the other side of the wall... sorry, I mean: sword).

• and how to stop your friend saying stupid things in Old Norse (the language of the Vikings). Use the expression: Stadva! But please try it ONLY if you really know what you’re doing (see the bad example of Tupac Shakur)

In our graphic novel we quote or paraphrase a few famous lines from well-known personalities, such as US Presidents Mr.Bush and Mr.Trump, Hannibal, Cicero, Terry Pratchett and Tupac himself,  and from films like Star Wars, The Grey, The Lord of the Rings and of course, from the Game of Thrones. Levi, our chief artist, depicted some emblematic pictures from movies: A Knight’s Tale and Robin Hood (these are easy to find), and from Black Hawk Down (THIS IS THE TRICKY ONE!!) You might get a prize if you find them.   

 

Our team, artists and others.

We are a multi-cultural Central European (we sometimes call it Austro-Hungarian) team with professionals from various areas of the arts and other professions.

CHRISTIAN - The Austrian Publisher: Christian Fischer, an old-time collector and comics fan is our main supporter on international waters. He supports us in building up the historical background for our story, mainly from old Austrian and Bavarian  sources. Additionally, Christian helps us on the Austrian market. 

LEVI - The Artist: The lead artist behind the project is Levi, one of the well-known graphic designers in Central-Eastern Europe. Levi graduated from the Hungarian Academy of Fine Arts. He used to be employed as an art director by multinational advertising agencies, but for many years he has been running his own graphic design company; Promotheos. It has become a recognized creative studio producing full design and organizing marketing for theatres, the largest cultural festivals in the region and international sports events (Fencing, Kayak-canoe, Gymnastics European and World Championships, Handball International tournaments).  He has won several awards for his work, including prizes from the Club of Hungarian Art Directors and the Graphic Designers Golden Pin Award. 

SINONIMO – The Writer: The story and the texts are the work of János Mészáros a.k.a Sinonimo. János started his career in the film and video business. He worked for Hungarian film distributing companies and operated multiplexes, where he was responsible for copywriting and marketing. After several exhausting years in the financial sector he swapped over to writing fiction (not including business plans any more...).

DÓRA KISTELEKI – The Painter: Dóra Kisteleki studied graphic art in the Faculty of Arts at the University of Kaposvár, Hungary. She is the illustrator of the West Plus literary magazine and has created cover graphics for various pop bands. Dóra has presented her works in pen, watercolour, ink and acrylic to the public several times with great success. Her pictures are always characterized by a hint of surrealism with a nice feminine touch. Several talented young painters and illustrators assisted Levi, such as BALÁZS PÁLFI, the Lakner sisters, Maja Németh, Nina Németh and last but not least the world famous TAMÁS GÁSPÁR, who  is a professional illustrator working in the publishing and entertainment industry for decades. His works range from cartoon and caricature style creations through to intricate and beautifully drawn illustrations for books, editorials, magazines and multi media projects. His most famous works include the Percy Jackson graphic novel series.

Still not convinced? If your answer is Yes, click below to read a 20-page preview of our graphic novel for free! www.kingsandcrosses.com/untoldstories

 

Perks

The Artbook pictures - selected by Levi


The Graphicum album - Includes the best Hungarian Graphic Designers' works (posters, logos, books, packaging and brochures) on 220 pages. Limited edition.

What the money is for     

The money being raised here will be used to cover the printing costs of the English language edition and some development costs for the Augmented Reality application.  

 Shipping

We have tried to get the best shipping rates for you. As we are in Europe, the shipping costs to the US could be really painfully high. But we set our shipping costs around USD 12-15. In case of special packages we are offering preferential fees .

Poster - The battlefield

For retailers  

We wholeheartedly support our retail partners. Please email kiralyokeskeresztek@gmail.com to discuss your wholesale order today. We look forward to hearing from you.  

 

 

If we raise more money... 

We have a whole nice array of plans lined up  to implement if we exceed the funding amount!

Firstly, we would like to make the app for IOS platform (iPad and Apple smartphones). 

Secondly, we are planning to include more characters and locations in the Augmented reality app.

story:
Story:

No matter how sophisticated we believe we have become as a people, and no matter how many Golden Ages of discovery we achieve, corruption, decadence, and complacency often cause the seeds of unrest to be shown between the haves and the have-nots.

Terry Holden, a single mother and Captain of a Venusian salvage spaceship, wants nothing more than to make a honest living. Her son, Percival, can't wait to start his first year studying abroad at a prestigious Martian college. When the Venusian Resistance attacks a prominent corporate headquarters, Mars goes into lock-down. Percival is detained by Martian authorities and Terry quickly finds herself torn between staying neutral to protect her livelihood, or risk everything to save her son.

Hollister Pelt III is an Asset Protection Enforcer tasked to save the Shirokawa Corporation from a hostile takeover. For the last year, he's been analyzing the disappearance of the mining vessel Ikarus and finally believes he knows the whereabouts of its very lucrative cargo. But some high ranking officials in the Mars Defense Directorate don't want to see Ikarus resurrected.... putting Hollister in their cross-hairs.

I wanted to create a science factual series containing historical and speculative elements, leading to a conflict between two factions of people on very different sides of the social hierarchy. ~ J. G. Birdsall

"Hard science fiction - that is, the kind of science fiction that gets into the nuts and bolts of science, discovery, and exploration - is underrepresented in movies and television. Venus Rises is therefore refreshing in its attention to the spacecraft and other technical details."

"Each character has a distinctive personality, from quirky to super-serious, which makes for an interesting mashup. This is one of those comics that has you eager to turn the page and continue reading"

"This is an exceptionally well-written piece of science fiction, which goes into detail about the science and engineering behind the story. It’s almost as if the creator has a degree in space travel!"

"If you're a fan of Firefly or Battlestar Galactica, you'll find VENUS RISES really attractive!"

What We Need:

We're looking to raise $3,000 in funding to help complete Exordium #2. $1,300 will go towards finishing the artwork, $1,500 covers the printing cost, and $200 will cover the printer's shipping charge. Exordium #2 will be 26 pages, in full color.

Choose between 2 different covers:

Rewards:

Exclusive small art prints by Wayne Lowdy & Robert Last. Check out Wayne's Instagram!

Exclusive VR T-shirts! Choose between 2 designs....

3D print of the Cattywompus by Gus Clark. Check out his Etsy shop! Get it painted or unpainted.

Exordium #1 has two covers to choose from. The standard cover showcases the Venusian crew, while the alternate cover (limited quantity) is of the Mars' protagonist.

The Official Companion is an in-depth look at Venus Rises, packed with behind-the-scenes interviews, many previously unpublished pictures, and a comprehensive episode guide. Featuring a Foreword by the show’s creator J. G. Birdsall, plus contributions from the production team.

Venus Rises was originally a web series, produced back in 2007. Relying heavily on physical sets, rather than green screen, it quickly became too costly to maintain.

Threshold is a two-part (black-and-white) comic that's a direct continuation of the web series.

Even if you can't contribute financially, you can still help us by spreading the word, help people find Venus Rises and get updates about the comic book. It will be greatly appreciated!

Team:

***The artwork for Issue #2 is near completion. We're aiming to have the comic and all rewards in your hand by August 2019 (if not sooner). This date may change due to unforeseen, real life day-to-day job, happenstances. We will keep you updated throughout all stages of development and any setbacks will be communicated to our backers.***

Stretch Goals:

1st: $3,000 - We complete Exordium #2! As a thank you, all backers who purchased a physical reward will get a VENUSRISES.TV bumper sticker!

2nd: $4,000 - Anyone who contributed $30 or more gets the Crew Concept poster print shipped to them for free!

3rd: $5,000 - Anyone who contributed $40 or more gets the Dueling Ships poster print shipped to them for free!

4th: $6,000 - Venus Rises: Exordium #3 is fully funded! Anyone who contributed $50 or more to the campaign will get a physical print copy of Exordium #3 when completed.

5th: $9,000 - Exordium #4 is fully funded! Anyone who contributed $50 or more will get a physical print copy of Exordium #4 when completed.

6th: $12,000 - Exordium #5 is fully funded! Anyone who contributed $50 or more will get a physical print copy of Exordium #5 when completed.

Thank you for joining the Venusian uprising!

Anyone who contributed $50 or more to the campaign will get a physical print copy of Exordium #3 when completed.5th: $9,000 - Exordium #4 is fully funded! Anyone who contributed $50 or more will get a physical print copy of Exordium #4 when completed.6th: $12,000 - Exordium #5 is fully funded! Anyone who contributed $50 or more will get a physical print copy of Exordium #5 when completed.Thank you for joining the Venusian uprising!

story:
The Beginning

I was a screenwriter and short film maker from Kansas City. I was fortunate enough to move to Los Angeles and learn from the best. When I met my mentor Scott C. Brown. He was able to teach me how to really write content. So I decided to do what I have always had the dream to do. COMICS! I was raised by my grandparents who passed away. I lived in their attic all the way till I graduated from college. I dedicate this to their memory. 2923 is my old street address. 29-23 Comics will provide unique comics for people of all different backgrounds

 

I'm have been putting my own money up to fund my project. I will be needing 2500 to fully complete the illustration of the comic. All funds will go directly to my artist to complete the products. I am also in the process of meeting with editors and publishing companies concerning my comic. This is hard work and I want to make sure I can complete this to the level my grandparents would want it. They are in the comic. WHY NOT?!

 

Artwork is always essential and your greatest investment

Petterson Hanz Oliveira, was born in Brazil in 1987 and a professional artist currently based in Florida. He started drawing when he was four years old and never stopped. Then in 2013 he decided to take a chance and attended The Kubert School. And in 2016  graduated the program. He has since been passionately pursuing his dream of drawing comics and always looking for the next opportunity.

Petterson is one of the best in the game. He has a investment in this project just as much as myself. I want to make sure he is taken care of and sees this project blossom to greatness.

 

There are no foreseen issues with the comic. I have a team that is already been working diligently to give a great product. Being independent has it ups and downs, but with this help I can move forward at a faster more efficient pace.

story:
Final-Final Update


See the comics Im making with the money raised in this campaign over at Tapastic, including Agents, Emi and Emma's spooky stories, Little Lee Hourly, and many more to come! 

Final Campaign Update



   The funds have been put to good use buying the printer/scanner combo, as seen in the brand new video. I am still working on comics and as soon as I finish the first issue I will send it out to all supporters in digital format, as well as asking again for an redeemable personalized perks. Thanks again for visiting!  Get ahold of me on twitter via @CtrlAltLee, on deviantart as AshleyAKnapp, or thru a comment on my website AshleyAKnapp.com . Thanks again! 

POST-CAMPAIGN UPDATE


Thanks! 
The campaign is over! Thanks to Alex, Scott, and the Anon who donated! It kept me energized and excited to work on this throughout the month. You have given me confidence that my work is worthwhile and I have room to improve. Also thanks to the promoters who spread the word of the campaign. 

Results
 Despite the support, I didn't reach my goal of $320, so I debated a bit about which of the things I listed I'm going to purchase to improve my art work.  
After some thinking about it, I'm going to purchase the scanner/printer combo.  This seems like the most practical purchase, since not only will it allow me to print out things like tickets, coupons, recipes, minicomics, and cards, but it will allow me to scan in traditional artwork that is jumbo sized. 
This will allow me to have original artwork for some of my series ( though some of them will still be all digital ) that I can preserve as art artifacts, or auction/sell/gift if my comics become popular in the future.  This will provide the potential for a future revenue stream to help my comics work become self-sustaining. 
Plus. my last scanner/printer lasted for around 7 years, so this will be a long term investment not likely to be out moded by technologies ever more rapid pace, like software or a webcam might be. 
What I Learned
Although I raised 50% of my goal, I had a few large donors rather then lots of small donors. After analyzing InSights, the promoter perks I was doing actually didn't bring in much traffic at all. This isn't a huge loss, since I enjoyed doing the perks, but it makes me realize that this isn't an effective way of promoting my campaign. I only had around 600 views total, which is less than the amount I got on a daily update for my old fancomic.
Another troubling aspect is that after running through initial responses on Gaia and DeviantArt forums and clubs, people stopped asking for free art. Both of the threads were dead by the end.  I know this isn't because my art is completely undesirable, as I've gotten paid gigs in the past. 
Perhaps making it free was too devaluing to the art, perhaps the fact that the promoter perks were unfinished pieces was another turn-off, or maybe it was the sites user base. I had absolutely no response on tumblr, twitter, or google plus. I need more engagement on all of these platforms.
My family was really supportive with this project, and I really appreciate the monetary and emotional encouragement to proceed with this project.
How Will I Apply This Knowledge?

Engagement and Entertainment are the two words on my mind. I need to give more to my followers/friends on the various social networks. Not only by supporting and following their work, but by providing entertainment as well. 
I think I need a series that updates weekly that can grow momentum like my old fan comic. However, I also need a way for people that are unfamiliar with me to find me accessible. 
The clear answer to this, looking at others around me, is fan art. In this vein, I've gotten back into doing a quick fanart sketch at the end of the night on a near-daily basis, and tagging them. None of them have had a huge response yet, but as my work and consistency improves I think I will find new people.  
However, most of my time is devoted to original content still, and I am creating a huge buffer of comic content so that I can start sharing my ideas again.  I am penciling every day. I am also continuing to outline and thumbnail future issues. I am continuing to warm up with reference or learning drawing for thirty minutes a day.


to Wrap It All up
Thanks to everyone who supported me, both financial and exposure wise! If and when I run a campaign again, I will ensure that I have more work to share, and have readers who are attached to said work. Getting this scanner/printer will be a huge step forward, not only providing a basic technology that is essential in many homes, but allowing me to fulfill a want I've had for years to be able to scan large sized bristol pages. Thanks so much for reading and the suppport! I will send out another round of notices for perk purchasers who have earned custom comics. These are redeemable until 2015. They will also receive digital copies of any comics I finish between now and 2015. 



I crave manga. Manga Studio EX 5 to be exact. And a scanner.

Thanks so much for visiting my page! Read on to find all about this fundraiser/commission sale!

  • Hi! I'm Ashley A Knapp. I'm a home-maker/artist. You might recognize me from around the web by my other pseudonyms, like CtrlAltLee. You can find me on various sites like youtube, deviantart, tumblr, and twitter. I'm passionate about comics and storytelling. I'm a frequent commenter on lifedrawing youtube series croquis cafe and even a one time  guest on comics podcast lean into art.  I'm ready to start my next comic series! 
  • I graduated college last winter and my student copy of Adobe Photoshop CS 5 ( the software I used to use to draw comics ) has expired. My scanner, which I've been using since 2008, also broke beyond repair two weeks ago.  I tried the trial of manga studio ex 5 and love it so far! It's amazingly intuitive and I feel like I could make much better comics much faster if I had a copy.  Since I only used Photoshop for illustration, this software seems like a good choice, and it comes highly recommended. 
  • Now the only obstacle keeping me from making comics like a madwomen is the fact that it is the trial version and I cannot, in fact, save anything I make yet. 

Thank you for reading all that! But this isn't all about me, I'm offering some great perks to those that help me out! First I'll break down what I'll be investing in with your help, and then I'll detail what you receive in return. 

What I Need

Here's where the $500 I'm raising will go:

  • Manga Studio EX 5 costs $299.99 on Smith macro's website, but I shopped around and found a physical copy on Amazon for about $90. I need $90 to get it. 


  • I would like to get a large format scanner so that I can draw and scan in on larger pieces of bristol board for pencils and traditional art pieces.  Many comic artists draw on bristol much larger then your letter sized scanner can handle.  I would like to buy this scanner/printer combo which has a larger 11x17 inch scan bed.  It is $300.00 normally, but only $230.00 on sale and has free shipping.


  • For those of you good at math, you'll notice that's only $320.00, leaving $180 left over. What would that be used for? 
BONUS
  • The remainder would go towards a high quality, hi-def web cam with mic so that I could broadcast my work flow during the day. I've already done some screen casting, but with a high end web cam with a good mic I could show both screen work and traditional art, enabling the ability for  all day shows on twitch, ustream, livestream, or google hangouts. The webcam I am considering is this one. If we reach this bonus I promise at least one 4-6 hour slot every week while I'll do requests for free live. 


     What if we do not reach $320?

    ( Strike through goals have already been achieved! Everyone is AWESOME! Thanks so much for how far we've gotten so far! ) 
    • If I don't reach my goal, I will purchase the tools I need to make comics in this order...  
    • $0-$20: Buy more india ink to traditionally do my comics that will only be seen via photos because I have no way to scan or letter them
    • $20-70: Buy Manga Studio 5 ( not EX 5 )  
    • $80-$200: Buy Manga Studio EX5
    • $200-$300: Buy Manga Studio EX 5 and a webcam that fits into budget of what is leftover
    • $320: Silly, that's the original goal! 

     All those pennies add up to comics pages

    As you can see no dollar is wasted, as I plan to put every penny towards creating art. Getting Manga Studio and the Scanner will enable me to share  the work easier with the world. 

    • Comics for everyone to read! 
    • When I start a project, I see it through to the end. Jackie Spicer might have been a silly fancomic, but it was a silly fancomic that updated almost daily for three years and saw it's conclusion posted, not fading into the ether unresolved like so many web comics do. If you get me this software and hardware I will make  sharing the comics I make with you my number one priority once again. this time with original characters and their stories straight from my heart.

    • ( Page 4 and page 500 of Jackie Spicer, roughly.  This is an example of my commitment, as it's from 2012 and no longer reflects my art ability.  For an example of the projects put on hiatus by my photoshop failure that would be resurrected if this campaign succeeds, see Dowry Quest and Sya Comic) 
    • EXAMPLE ART FROM DOWRY QUEST


    • EXAMPLE ART FROM SYA COMIC

    Risks & Challenges

    Things don't always go the way we plan. Here's the backup plan in case things get rocky. B|

    Risks

    • RISK:Manga Studio's sales on Amazon could End
    • SOLUTION: The money that would have gone towards the scanner will make up the difference and Manga Studio will be bought no matter what.
    • RISK: I will not make art once I get the programs
    • SOLUTION: Feel free to click any of the social media profiles I linked to in the introduction above to see me uploading every single week from now until back in 2009. I can't be stopped ( muahaha ) , although losing my scanner and photoshop admittedly slowed me considerably. Unless my arms fall off, this won't be an issue. 
    • RISK: The minumum goals aren't met
    • SOLUTION: I will spend the money on india ink and paper and keep toiling away in private. Your  money will be spent making those comics happen. although the best way I will have to share them for a while is in photo form. ( like this


    If you can't contribute money but still want to read these comics, fear not! 

    It's cool if you can't give cash towards this particular comics cause.

    • Use those indiegogo share tools! Perhaps you know someone who can chip in?
    • Go to a local restaurant and discreetly leave the url to this campaign on random napkins tucked away in the napkin holders, that way people will be like 'time to wipe my hands- oh what's this? I BETTER ENTER IT INTO MY ADDRESS BAR AND SEE.' And thus we will raise a billion jillion smackaroos without you having to contribute a dime. It's so mad it might just work! 

    Aaaaand this is long enough, so time to show you what you get in return for helping me! this isn't a charity so much as commissions with a set goal, and I am so excited to share the perks with you! 


    REWARDS

    Since the perks widget doesn't let me post images, let me post examples here:
    $1  A personalized thank you image with your name! 


    $5 A chibi social media icon, you can let me design it or request something specific



    $10 Chibi fully colored




    $20 Anime/cartoon character with color






    $100 Your own Black and White comic, one issue.  18-22 pages. Lots of communications and working closely together to make sure it comes out exactly as you want. Pencils and layouts can be started before campaign ends, the final inking and lettering will wait until after campaign finishes so I can draw it at 600dpi print quality. :) 


    $500 - A full bodied, color comic of 18-22 pages. An issue.. This would involve lots of communication, multiple chat sessions, revisions, etc.  Pencils and layouts can be started before campaign ends, the final inking and letting will wait until after campaign finishes so I can draw and color it at 600dpi print quality. :)  Here's an example of what one panel might look like


    Thank you to my wonderful funders! 
    Thank you so much to the funders so far! I now have enough to buy manga studio, and I am quickly approaching being able to buy the jumbo sized scanner as well! 
    A special thanks to Alex, our first funder, who got this party started and who declined the comic reward. His awesome new avatar in full camo facepaint can be seen in the gallery, and of course he can ask his comic any time now or through all of 2015 if he changes his mind! He got us off to a great start!

    An additional enthusiastic accolade must go out to Scott, the second backer who snatched up the $100 tier over the weekend, so that I came back to an amazing awesome Monday surprise! Let me know when you want your perks by getting in touch whenever you want! :) Thank you Scott!

    And now we're only five dollars away from the halfway point ( $250 ) after a mysterious anonymous dropped off a cool $45.  That's not even a burger meal way from the halfway point! Whooo! That $45 would buy a lot of comics, and will go towards the creations of dozens and dozens of pages more. Thanks so much for this awesome donation Anon, I adore you and you're generosity!

story:
UPDATE #1:

First off, a HUGE thank you to those who have donated thus far. You are all the best!

Secondly, I've got a printer now so I'm one step closer to making this thing a reality! I'll be getting the toner/paper/staples and such soon and will get down to making some test books later in the month.

-Matt

Who's this guy? What's his story?

My name is Matt Cummings and I'm a freelance illustrator from Nova Scotia, Canada.

In 2010 I started a webcomic called Bluenose. It's a fun adventure story featuring vegetable witches, robotic dogs and a dude made of corn!

To date, Bluenose has 3 chapters and 250+ pages. I had to take a haitus from the comic due to time contraints but now I'd like to relaunch it in a big bad way!

In September there's a gathering of indie comics creators in Bethesda, Maryland called SPX (Small Press Expo). It's my goal to travel there and premier an all-new printed Bluenose book! Whoa!

Needs, wants, plans, REWARDS!

The costs I need to cover are those of printing, travel and production of my book.

Right now, some of my best flight options are in the $500-600 range. I'll be working myself silly to cover extra travel costs but the biggest barrier currently are the tickets and additional travel on the ground.

Next, and most importantly, would be printing and production costs for the books. I'm looking to print between 150-200 for the initial run in black and white. I'll be printing/assembling them myself to save on shipping costs so I'll need funds for the raw materials only: Printer, paper, ink, stapler, staples, love. The more money I'm able to raise, the better the book will look!

I'll also need to cover the time spent making the book. Although most of it will be done in my off-hours, I'll still need to take a little time away from my usual commission work to design, assemble and ship my minis out.

MORE IMPORTANTLY??? Incentives!

For donating $5 and up, you'll get a handsome digital copy (PDF) of the book!

Pay a little bit more and I'll throw in 2 digital, ready-for-print sized Bluenose illustrations, one of which has never been seen by internet eyes before!

Perks for higher donor levels include an actual real-life copy of the book for your hands/eyes and sketches of your wonderful faces done in the Bluenose style!

The Impact

This is my first forray into the world of printed comics and I couldn't be more excited! I'm in love with the work I've created for the book and I can't wait to share it with everyone.

Combined with the opportunity to meet-and-greet those of you who'll be able to attend SPX this year and give you a copy in person, this entire campaign will be a dream come true for me.

No money? You can still help!

If you can't contribute any money, DON'T WORRY! I'm in the same boat a lot of the time. In fact, I've been made the honourary captain of that boat.

I'd appreciate any forwarding/sharing you could do across social media - Twitters, Facebooks, tumblrs! MSN your grandma and see what she has to say about it. I humbly thank you so so much for any sharing you do!
story_txt:
UPDATE #1:
First off, a HUGE thank you to those who have donated thus far. You are all the best!
Secondly, I've got a printer now so I'm one step closer to making this thing a reality! I'll be getting the toner/paper/staples and such soon and will get down to making some test books later in the month.
-Matt
Who's this guy? What's his story?
My name is Matt Cummings and I'm a freelance illustrator from Nova Scotia, Canada.
In 2010 I started a webcomic called Bluenose. It's a fun adventure story featuring vegetable witches, robotic dogs and a dude made of corn!
To date, Bluenose has 3 chapters and 250+ pages. I had to take a haitus from the comic due to time contraints but now I'd like to relaunch it in a big bad way!
In September there's a gathering of indie comics creators in Bethesda, Maryland called SPX (Small Press Expo). It's my goal to travel there and premier an all-new printed Bluenose book! Whoa!


Needs, wants, plans, REWARDS!
The costs I need to cover are those of printing, travel and production of my book.
Right now, some of my best flight options are in the $500-600 range. I'll be working myself silly to cover extra travel costs but the biggest barrier currently are the tickets and additional travel on the ground.
Next, and most importantly, would be printing and production costs for the books. I'm looking to print between 150-200 for the initial run in black and white. I'll be printing/assembling them myself to save on shipping costs so I'll need funds for the raw materials only: Printer, paper, ink, stapler, staples, love. I'll also need to cover the time spent making the book. Although most of it will be done in my off-hours, I'll still need to take a little time away from my usual commission work to design, assemble and ship my minis out.

story:
Assalam aleykum!

My name is Ubaydullah I am from dergah of Sheikh Nazim in Lefke, Cyprus for last 5-6 years living here. Working with Sheikh Mehmet personally in gardens. And I run website BeRabbani.com calling people to support Sheikh Mehmet and follow him since 3-4 years already. Now Sheikh Nazim passed away few weeks ago and Sheikh Mehmet took his place as Sultan ul Awlia.

I had inspiration one year ago and I asked Sheikh Mehmet personally about making this and many other projects like selling his big photos. Among them I asked what If I make comics book from Sheikh Nazim sohbhets and surprisingly he said "You can do this". It felt like he knew this idea before I spoke. Of course he knew he is Sultan of Saints.

Anyway I didn't do anything about it yet but now few weeks ago Sheikh Nazim passed away and I want to do this comics book about him as a memory.

So anyone who wish to help to rise me start point with 5000$ in this 40 days come and send me your donations.

This will be enough for me to make a first edition of comics book and if people will enjoy this I may continue doing this more. I can print out for free over 100 copy and spread it among visitors of Lefke dergah included in this price.

This is tough job but this Idea came to me after Pope John Paul II died and his comic books was spread in Brasil and other countries for free over 100.000.000 copies.

But our people muslims are not so good like christians in helping to rise memory of highest saints. So let's start with 5000$ for pilot edition and 100 cipies first and see what comes later. Hopefully to increase this to 10.000 copies later! That may require another crowd funding campaign after this one is done.

Sheikh Nazim is real saint to whom Pope Benedict came upon call and became his student. Sheikh Nazim described it as that new Pope was looking for real saints from holy books on earth and he found Sheikh Nazim is real one. This video is available on youtube if you like and was on Italian TV.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ULgGMf1r3lo

If I don't reach my entire goal the funds will go to support my other projects like sufi lesson education project and building up photo gallery in Lefke of Sheikh Mehmet lifestyle. Also making dedicated video shooting of Sheikh Mehmet sohbets by myself in Ubaydullah Rabbani film studio professional standarts with website for this as well. Actually I need money for this all things but just let's start with something and go on later with the rest! Inshallah.

My project is valuable for the world because Sheikh Nazim appreciated my jobs that I was doing before and he always said "Thank you" to me, Ubaydullah.

He said I am clever and I have adab and doing great service for Grandsheikhs.

Sheikh Mehmet also did a lot of training on me to make me good quality control on anything I do. Other people can't do things that I am doing because of that. What they do is all non spiritual crap made up in their imaginations only. Websites and anything they do around this tariqa in "official" way doesn't cost a penny. Spoiled milk as Sheikh Nazim said should be thrown away. This is not politics or business. AwliaAllah are very demanding to spiritual cleanness of any jobs around. And nobody here cares of this except me and Sheikh Mehmet.

I have experience on exploring Sheikh Nazim speech for years and I know how to explain his talks that needs explanation. That's why also my comic book must be the best to bring out the major points to people who read them. This is heart inspirations Sheikh Nazim put in my heart from his sohbets or was it Sheikh Mehmet actually? Because Sheikh Mehmet is the one who understand him best. Other people resisted following Sheikh Mehmet for all this years. Including high level followers all were against me and my call to follow him.

Anyway today I want to bring a lot of things to the world because Sheikh Nazim said few years ago just before I made my website BeRabbani.com 

"I can keep you here for few month but it is not true for more. 

You must go out of dergah and teach people what you have learned" 

in his sohbet adressing derwishes like us who spent years with him.

Later I also consult with Sheikh Mehemt about anything I do.

Both of them supporting me with symbolic money that has energy. 

Usually when someone of Sultan ul Awlia gives like 20$ it has energy to bring more than 1000 times more from other people and sources later. 

And that is also how I started this charity campaign I have already mashallah.

Sheikh Mehmet gave me symbolic money when I had no money and I was asking on internet for 5 supporters with 50 euro every 2 weeks and same week I got 5 supporters with 50 euro every 2 weeks that I was looking for and told him that "Nobody giving me charity money except one". So he gave me symbolic money and boom! 5 or more people that I needed appeared.

So the power of AwliaAllah is not giving money but giving symbolic money so other people may contribute later as charity. This is prooved method by any old sufi murid representative can tell you this is true - they know this is the way of Sheikh Nazim and Sheikh Mehmet and any Sultan ul Awlia.

Anyway If you can't help me with money to make this comic book or other stuff then bring the word out to your public and help me to get more known with this.

Use Indiegogo share tools! Share this link to this campaign to others.

This is prooved method by any old sufi murid representative can tell you this is true - they know this is the way of Sheikh Nazim and Sheikh Mehmet and any Sultan ul Awlia.Anyway If you can't help me with money to make this comic book or other stuff then bring the word out to your public and help me to get more known with this.Use Indiegogo share tools! Share this link to this campaign to others.

story:
"...och se, där kom en gris, blott en kulting, men liten, skär och stygg. Och på midvinternatten i det trettonde året i den nya tiden band han svarta ord i en liten skrift. Och lärjungarna suckade, att väntan var över, ty nu öppnades den likt en port och det, som varit fördolt, blev var mans egendom. Men ve er som läser, ty ert skinn skall vända sig, mungiporna dras bak och djuret inom ta plats i ert anlete så att ni snart slutar på julbordet"

 - Abdul Alhazred


Tiden är inne

Necronasses Lilla Svarta ligger klar att möta pressarna. Citatboken med Den Skäre Mästarens visdom väntar bara på att stjärnorna står...

...nej nu blev det fel. Necronasse har flyttat stjärnorna till rätt position för länge sen, nu behövs bara villiga offer från oskyldiga plånböcker! Necronasse vill att Du känner efter i ditt torra, svarta lilla hjärta och skänker en slant så att boken blir av!

För detta lovar han att offra dig sist, eller kanske inte. Men i varje fall först efter det att du fått en bok eller lite roliga grejer. 


Vem är då Necronasse?

Kanske är det här första gången du hör talas om honom eller Nasses Nekrozin. Här kommer några ord om ämnet.

1998 gick ett gäng personer på Serietecknarskolan i Hofors tillsammans, de bestämde sig för att åka på spelkonvent till Göteborg och behövde ett lagnamn. Någonstans framträdde orden "Nasses Nekromantiker". Tanken på den lille Nasse som överhuvud för ett ondsint brödraskap av svartmagiker gav många ideer och vi bestämde oss för att sätta ihop några av våra serier till en tidning. Nasses Nekrozin var fött...

Vi lyckades inte sälja så många exemplar av #1 men hade så kul när vi gjorde det att vi bestämde oss för att försöka igen året därpå. Den gången gick det bättre och vi sålde hela upplagan på 100 exemplar! Framgångarna sporrade oss och till dags dato har det blivit 19 nummer och två album!

Med tiden har skaran av kreatörer växt till sig, några har fallit bort längs vägen men andra har kommit till istället tills vi nu räknar runt 20 tecknare. Varje medlem har ett alter ego som en av Necronasses slavar, en brokig samling av zombies, galna doktorer, elaka tomtar och annat pack.

Vår lilla värld har en väldigt egen lukt som vi nu vill förmedla på ett nytt sätt, därför har vi bjudit in tecknare utifrån för att hjälpa oss visualisera Necronasses samlade visdomar. Boken innehåller 52 uppslag med citat och illustrationer i färg från ett otal förtappade tecknarsjälar!

Hjälp oss sprida vår farsot av serier, dumheter, våld och rollspel.

Hoppa på tåget mot världens kant.

Bli en i den viljelösa skara proselyter som hörsammar Necronasses kall och crowdfunda Necronasses Lilla Svarta!


Vilka medverkar?

Fredrik Andersson 
Emma Anderstedt 
Daniel Ankarsten 
Anders Backlund 
Jenny Berggrund 
Malin Biller 
Johan Cedmar Brandstedt 
Fanny M. Bystedt 
Jimmy Bäckström 
Johnie Ekman 
Sebastian Ericson
Marie Eriksson
Stef Gaines
Max Gustafson
Yvette Gustafsson
Jenny Hannula
Oscar Hjelmgren
Karl Holmqvist
Hedvig Häggman-Sund
Björn Härgestam
Randi Johansson
Nickan Jonasson
Nicolas Krizan
Jan Kustfält
Daniel Lenneér
PG Lidström
Nathalie Nilsson
Magnus "Mojo" Olsson 
Henrik Sahlström
Magnus Sundin
Malin Svedjeholm
Petter Thomée
Jimmy Wallin
Li Österberg

Och som grädde på moset har Anders Fager skrivit förordet.

 

Vad vi behöver

Korv såklart, alla älskar korv! Nej, allvarligt talat, vi behöver ca 13 000 kr till trycket av 500 ex och 7000 till kringkostnader, avgifter och frakt. Om vi når längre än vårt mål kommer vi att göra boken snyggare. Mer detaljer  om det här kommer, följ vår FB-sida Nasses Nekrozin så får du uppdateringar när det händer nåt!

Om du bidrar får du specialgrejs™ samt såklart ära och odöd tacksamhet!

Når vi inte vårt mål trycker vi boken ändå på nåt vis, men det tar längre tid...


Varför bidra?

Vi anser att världen av idag behöver ett skratt till och lite mindre respekt för auktoriteter. I Nasses Nekrozin finns inte respekt i ordets verkliga bemärkelse, bara en rädsla för en liten, ond gris...

Det var mitt försök att vara allvarlig, nu till grisens kärna! Grillat är godast! Du vet att du vill ha det! Det är dumt, fullt med klyschor och namedropping, har du läst Nasses Nekrozin tidigare så vet du vad jag pratar om och varför det är värt det trots bristen på...
Ja bristen helt enkelt!

Nasses Nekrozin är fanzinet som vägrar dö, trots ändlösa sågningar har vi en stark fanbase med gott om självdistans som har sett tidningen komma ut sen 1998. Bespottad av kritikerkåren men älskad av zombien på gatan, dvs du. Ta chansen att se nya, omöjliga vinklar på Necronasse, jag kan lova att du inte sett dem i tryck förut!


Om du inte har råd...

...finns det ändå sätt att bidra. Sprid ordet, dela vidare vår kampanj! Vi funderar på att fixa perks även till de som värvar andra.

Moh / K. Våldshämnaren

story:
I went to a roller derby game with a friend in 2006 or 2007 and after the game one of the skaters came up to me to try to recruit me for the team as a skater; it's awesome, she said, and fun. "No thanks,"  I told her. "I like my teeth in my head."

Well, she said. You could ref.

Officiating* roller derby is awesome and weird. I've been at this since 2008 or so, and I've amassed a lot of hilarity in the meantime. I've officiated in three countries (getting stinky gear and skates through customs was less tricky than anticipated), run through airports trying to get connecting flights, reffed in a hurricane (twice) and in a horse barn (once, maybe twice?), and navigated crabby teams, ornery officials, structural mayhem (sometimes it's so humid it actually rains INSIDE of the rinks...), and other wacky nonsense.

I drove halfway across the country once to officiate (it's a hilarious story now), was forced to call off a game once at the exact half (that's a hell of a story), coordinated a couple of tournaments, learned how to jam ref (despite still being kind of terrible at it), got streaked once while I was working a game (YOU KNOW WHO YOU ARE), survived minor penalties (oh Godzilla nooooo), a pizzaquest in STL, and survived (okay, perpetuated) a whoooooole  lot of pranks, ridiculous road trips, and tequila shots. Our outfits might not be as rad as skater outfits, but it's still a pretty sweet hobby.**

Some of you know these stories. But by the end of this book, you'll know all of my favorites. When I started officiating, the average shelf life of a roller derby official was about 2 years. I've been at it for quite a bit longer. There's gotta be some good stories in there...

What I Need & What You Get

Otherwise known as the money stuff...

I'm printing with Lulu.com (again) because of their flexible publication options and because they did a great job with both of my previous books. My goal is to do a signed and numbered first printing of between 150 and 200 copies of So You're A Ref...?, to have stock to bring to various shows and distribution networks and also to get the books to my backers. Each book costs about $6 to produce -- about $900 to about $1200 depending on final page counts (around 100 or so digest-size pages is my projection; initial story planning suggests that it'll land somewhere in the 100-120 page range) and total final copies.

$350 of this campaign covers the cost of the lengthy and tedious process of converting the 100+ drawn pages into a digital format. In the interest of finishing in a timely fashion, I'm getting some help from a fellow artist on this one, because I want to support another working artist as part of this project.

The last $400 of this proposal covers the assorted shipping costs of getting books to me and then getting the books to you (postage costs about $3 per copy in the US, and international is $12! Ooof!) and various other expenses (mailers, promotional material, sample copies, fundraising fees, etc.) associated with printing a long form book and crowdsourcing the funding.

My goal is to finish this book no matter what happens with the fundraising. So if I don't hit my minimum goal, there will still be something in your mailbox. I'm using this crowdfunding plan as a way to get the collection done; that accountability is a major part of why I chose the flexible funding option rather than the fixed all-or-nothing funding option.

Perks!

Everyone loves perks? I wanted to do a combination of cool things and essential things -- so the perks are both practical and quirky, and also reflect my artistic interests these days. They're mostly roller derby themed, in keeping with the theme of the book, but your support helps me keep publishing my work.

Risks & Challenges

I've successfully completed two previous book projects via Indiegogo, so the risk of non-completion is pretty low, in my opinion. The primary challenge for me is making sure to hit my deadlines, but I have a hard deadline -- I'd like to debut this book at the Small Press Expo in Bethesda in September, so my production timeline reflects that. 

I'm planning to create the bulk of this work during the time that this campaign runs. By the end of the 30 days I intend to have the majority of the work (if not all of it) fully completed. My goal is to hand the pages off to the rad human who's going to convert them to digital files by mid-to-late June, so that July can be spent scanning, proofing, etc. and the books can go to press by early August, which should ideally leave enough time for books to arrive by SPX in mid-September and ship to backers shortly afterwards.  I'll also post some of the material here as I finish it, so you can stay current on my progress toward those goals.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't donate, you can still help. Sharing the link among your social networks to get the word out is incredibly helpful.  I'll update this site with sketches and news as the project moves forward so you can stay in touch and watch how it goes!

Thanks, folks.

Anne

(aka Anne Persand)

* I'm going to use the word officiating a lot, because it's more inclusive: as an official I sometimes work as a referee and sometimes I work as a non-skating official, and I see these things as pretty linked. Working as an NSO makes refs better, in my opinion, and NSOs are the real backbone of games; it's hard, underappreciated work that deserves to be recognized for what it is.

 

** So, the working title for this book while it was in development was Derby Shorts, because it's short stories and  short shorts, and when people think of roller derby they still channel their inner Tina Belcher and think about butts. But(t) that's also the title of a book that For Books' Sake in collaboration with the London Rollergirls published a couple of years ago. So, the title changed, but the butts remain.
story_txt:
I went to a roller derby game with a friend in 2006 or 2007 and after the game one of the skaters came up to me to try to recruit me for the team as a skater; it's awesome, she said, and fun. "No thanks,"  I told her. "I like my teeth in my head."
Well, she said. You could ref.
Officiating* roller derby is awesome and weird. I've been at this since 2008 or so, and I've amassed a lot of hilarity in the meantime. I've officiated in three countries (getting stinky gear and skates through customs was less tricky than anticipated), run through airports trying to get connecting flights, reffed in a hurricane (twice) and in a horse barn (once, maybe twice?), and navigated crabby teams, ornery officials, structural mayhem (sometimes it's so humid it actually rains INSIDE of the rinks...), and other wacky nonsense.
I drove halfway across the country once to officiate (it's a hilarious story now), was forced to call off a game once at the exact half (that's a hell of a story), coordinated a couple of tournaments, learned how to jam ref (despite still being kind of terrible at it), got streaked once while I was working a game (YOU KNOW WHO YOU ARE), survived minor penalties (oh Godzilla nooooo), a pizzaquest in STL, and survived (okay, perpetuated) a whoooooole  lot of pranks, ridiculous road trips, and tequila shots. Our outfits might not be as rad as skater outfits, but it's still a pretty sweet hobby.**
Some of you know these stories. But by the end of this book, you'll know all of my favorites. When I started officiating, the average shelf life of a roller derby official was about 2 years. I've been at it for quite a bit longer. There's gotta be some good stories in there...

What I Need & What You Get
Otherwise known as the money stuff...

I'm using this crowdfunding plan as a way to get the collection done; that accountability is a major part of why I chose the flexible funding option rather than the fixed all-or-nothing funding option.

Everyone loves perks? I wanted to do a combination of cool things and essential things -- so the perks are both practical and quirky, and also reflect my artistic interests these days. story:
Chapter Four, TIME

In the fourth chapter, we follow Tim's path into adulthood, the highs and the lows of a young man uncertain of his place, his path, and his own identity after losing his lifelong friend. We learn more about the events that cast his life into hermitage, and how it is shaped by his own choices and cruelly-spun fate. Between Tim's grudging memories, the real world brought back to him by Ellis' return eat away at his uncomfortable shell, the frustration and confusion threaten his sanity and drive him farther into the bottle. Nostalgia and the machine of the present tear at each other in this fourth chapter of Our Time in Eden as Ellis and Tim struggle to hide from the encroachment of TIME.


From author Gibson Twist and artist Ben Steeves, Our Time in Eden is a story of lost innocence, lost direction, and lost hope. The promises and lies of childhood, the endurance and heartbreak of friendship, and the bitter consequence of tasting the fruit of knowledge.

Here we are seeking funds to print the fourth chapter in this engrossing and deeply-emotional comic series.

 

What's On Offer?

As with the previous campaigns for this series, we're offering copies of this 30-page black and white comic, and for new readers we're also offering packages with all four issues, Ch 1, Fatigue, Ch 2, Innocence, Ch 3. Lost, and Ch 4 Time.

In addition, for this campaign we are offering campaign-exclusive 5x7prints by artist Ben Steeves, author Gibson Twist, and celebrated artist Rori! Get one of your choice or all three, including one copy of the book, final art to be revealed. You can also get our full package, including all four books and all three prints.

Retailer packages are also available upon request, so bug your local comic shop to come on out to the party. All copies of Ch 4 will include a unique bookplate exclusive to this IndieGogo campaign.

The comic is ready to print, we're just waiting for funds to skyrocket into the universe!


 

The Story of The Story

Our Time in Eden began as a novel, written by Gibson Twist in 1995, then languished for many years. Gibson met Ben Steeves in 2005 at a local comic-making event, teaming up in 2006 to win cash and prizes in a collaborative comicking marathon, About Comics' Comic Jam War. A unique artistic connection formed quickly between them, and they began discussing a larger project. Ben chose Our Time in Eden.

 

The project was first posted online at ourtimeineden.smackjeeves.com in 2008, gaining critical acclaim and small, devoted audience. Ben and Gibson are now bringing the series to print, continuing with this fourth chapter, TIME.

More of Ben's work can be found at talesofgravedanger.tumblr.com and instagram.com/bensteamroller , and Gibson's long-running comic Pictures of You can be found at picturesofyoucomic.com, Rori's most recent project is the #100Women100Days project which can be found with her other work at roricomics.tumblr.com

story:
Who We Are 

Hello from the founders of Comic Arts Richmond (CAR)! The CAR team is Christine Skelly and Francesca Lyn. Skelly is the Creative Director of CAR. In addition to her extensive knowledge of print production and design, she organized the Working Artist Lyceum for two years.  Francesca is a comics scholar who teachers at Virginia Commonwealth University and helps organize the Small Press Expo (SPX) in Bethesda, Maryland. 

It has been our dream to bring a local independent comics show to Richmond, Virginia. We are committed to having the best show possible.  We have secured our location, gotten wonderful exhibitors, and are ready to go! 

What We Need & What You Get

Besides hosting the event at Strangeways Brewing, we are currently have no advertisers or sponsors. We are also committed to keeping table fees low which leaves us with a very small budget. This campaign offsets some of our advertising costs. Having this campaign also allows us to used Indiegogo as a preorder system, allowing us to keep our costs down. 

We both work full-time and need some help. We believe that this work should be fairly compensated. This campaign will allow us to pay someone to help us the day of. We are also issuing print stipends to cartoonists. Any money left over will be used towards next year's show. 

The Impact

We both love comics and we love the local Richmond comics community. This campaign would allow us to support the local comics community with more than just a fun event by allowing us to provide tangible benefits to them. We want CAR to be an annual event and this is our first step. 

Risks & Challenges

We have everything in place to have all of our merchandise ready for sale. We are working with a local screenprinter and both have extensive experience with fulfillment. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We totally understand that money is tight. If you can't make a financial contribution please share this campaign to help spread the word.

story:
Ciao, sono Davide La Rosa. Ancora io, sì. Sono tornato.

Per chi si fosse perso la campagna dell'anno scorso. Io sono nato a Como nel 1980, e faccio i fumetti (sono autore, tra le altre cose di "Suore ninja"; "Paco Lanciano e il fagiano crononauta"; "Ugo Foscolo indagatore dell'incubo"; "La Bibbia 2"; "Il libretto rosso del trio occhialuto antifascista"; e altri fumetti). Tecnicamente sarei uno sceneggiatore ma, spesso, mi ritrovo a fare storie scritte e disegnate da me. Quindi sono un autore completo… come completo è il disastro dei miei disegni. Già, non so disegnare. Però pare che questi disegni funzionino con le cose che racconto. PARE eh, mica lo so se è vero… ai posteri l’ardua sentenza (dannati posteri, sempre lì pronti a giudicare).
Comunque.
Un giorno mi sono detto: “Davide, perché non illustri, male, tutta la Divina Commedia di Dante Alighieri?”. Ho lanciato una campagna per l'Inferno e andò particolarmente bene. Quindi ora sono qui a proporvi la seconda cantica: il Purgatorio!

I motivi per comprare questo libro (che uno potrebbe pensare essere inutile perché tanto Dorè lo ha fatto benissimo prima di me) sono 3:

1) Dorè era bravo a disegnare, facile illustrare quando si è bravi a disegnare. Provate voi ad essere incapace e illustrare 33 canti (che ora sono 67, visto che ho già fatto i 34 dell'Inferno).

2) Dorè è morto.

3) Il 2021 è l'anno in cui si celebrano i 700 anni dalla morte di Dante.

Il libro, brossurato, sarà di circa 240 pagine in bianco e nero. Dentro ci sarà il testo originale di Dante (che tanto, come detto sopra, è morto da 700 anni e non mi può denunciare) e tutto sarà illustrato da me (che per ora sono vivo quindi magari mi denuncio da solo… decido in settimana). Ci saranno circa 3 o 4 illustrazione a canto, per immortalare i momenti più salienti di un’opera immortale.

story:
The Golden Thread Project is a celebration of folk song and the graphic arts. Collaborating with the English Folk Dance & Song Society we have created an exhibition which celebrates a seminal moment in folk history. 29 artists have created comic strips and illustrations based on this moment and on March 13th 2018 we are exhibiting this work at Cecil Sharp House in London.

With this campaign we aim to make enough money to publish a book, we would also like to create an online educational resource where people can learn about global folk cultures via beautiful artwork.The Golden Thread Project book is a 180-page full colour collection, adapting folk songs from the 1920s to today into comic strips by a dazzling array of creators from across the comics and printmaking spectrum. The lineup:

MARK STAFFORD adapts ‘The Cruel Ship’s Carpenter’
ORSON COUPLAND adapts ‘King Kong Kitchie Kitchie Kim-E-O’
AIDAN SAUNDERS adapts ‘The Big Rock Candy Mountain’
KIMBERLEY FOUNTAIN adapts ‘Lord Ronald/Lord Randal’
DREW WEBSTER adapts ‘Spanish Ladies’
HANNAH DYSON adapts ‘The False Knight On The Road ‘
PETER LLOYD adapts ‘The Farmer’s Curst Wife’
JONNY HANNAH  adapts ‘St. James Infirmary Blues’
BETTE-BELLE BLANCHARD adapts ‘The Cruel Mother’ 
DARYL RAINBOW adapts ‘Gallows Pole/Hangman’  
ZEEL adapts ‘Fatal Flower Garden/Hugh of Lincoln’  
NICK WHITE  adapts ‘The Carrion Crow’
HUNT EMERSON adapts ‘Froggy Went A’Courtin’ 
SOJU TANAKA adapts ‘Old Roger is Dead’ 
LESLEY BARNES adapts ‘The Trees they Grow so High’ 
MARIE MORELLE  adapts ‘Scarborough Fair’
JIM STOTEN  adapts ‘John of Hazelgreen’
FIONTAN FITZGERALD adapts ‘Nottamun Town’
FRAN COLOMB adapts ‘The Foggy, Foggy Dew’
LORD HURK adapts ‘The Two Brothers’
BEAU BRANNICK adapts ‘Black Is The Colour’
JONATHAN EDWARDS adapts ‘The Cherry Tree Carol’
TOMMY BRENTNALL adapts ‘Lady Isabel and the Elf Knight’ 
STEVEN FOWLER adapts ‘And We Hunted And We Hunted/Three Jolly Welshmen’
GARY NORTHFIELDhe adapts ‘Three Ravens’
ROB NICOL adapts ‘What Are Little Boys Made Of ?’ and  ‘The Tottenham Toad’  
WOODROW PHOENIX adapts ‘Single Girl, Married Girl’  

If we reach our goal of £850 that would award us enough money to publish an E-book and start a website which can run for 2 years,

If we make £1500 we can launch an e-book, a website and a very ltd edition of books,

With £3000 we can publish a run of books, start our website and embark on an exciting future with 'The Golden Thread Project'.

    All patrons will be celebrated on our website, if you are unable to donate please could you share this campaign on any social media platforms you may have.

    Thank You!

story:
A comic about Helen Arambula, a 12 year old overweight girl in junior high school.  She's nerdy, she's homely to look at, she's kind of a mess, no one at school really likes her.

But when she gets home, she puts on her cosplay outfit, grabs a huge laser gun, and stands around in her bedroom, waiting to be teleported to an alien planet full of crazy monsters that she fights in her giant battle machine spraying lasers and missiles everywhere!

But does she actually teleport?  Will she wait in her bedroom the whole time, for the entire rest of the comic, just standing there?  Read the comic to find out!

Although no, she does teleport, it wouldn't be much of a comic otherwise.

Also you can't read the comic to find out yet, because I need the money to pay for the rest of the pages.  That's where we need your help!

We are Ran'Deesha Diaz (the writer) and Jacqueline Deglass (artist) and we've loved comics for many years, and we've finally decided to try making our own.

We want to make this comic because we think it would be a fun comic to read, for us and for anyone else.  Comics have a special advantage that no other medium has, because they can take the reader places that would take hundreds of millions of dollars for a movie or TV show to pull off, they can involve a reader visually in a way text can't, and they can go beyond the limits of imagination to do things no one thought of before, especially with characters no one's ever tried to make before.  We want to make comics like that!

Literally #1, what's it about?

It's a sort of bizarre satirical comedic action story that focuses on Helen Arambula, an overweight 12 year old Mexican girl who goes to an ordinary junior high school.  She seems like an average nerdy girl in school, but when she gets home, she puts on her cosplay outfit and teleports to another planet where endless swarms of monsters have to be fought back, and she joins a rag tag team of colorful diverse characters in fighting the monsters, while also balancing their normal daytime lives.  Helen's troubles are unique due to her situation, and how she interacts with her fellow mech jockeys leads to a lot of fun and exciting situations in combat.  And there's plenty of combat, with mechs stomping around and big crazy monsters attacking, and Helen is in the middle of all of it.

The pages, as funded so far, will be in black and white, as I'm unable to afford color, HOWEVER if we exceed our funding goal, I will use the extra money to get the comic colored, no problem!  Any money beyond that will be used to fund Literally #2.

What we're gonna do with that sweet sweet MONEY

The entire comic series has been fully scripted, the concept art is wrapped up, and the first couple of pages are already finished.

However, I've had to pay Jacqueline with my own money for the first few pages, and it sucks to admit, but I ran out of money and went into debt trying to make this comic, because I'm so determined to make a real comic book after just thinking about it for years.

The funding goes directly to paying for the remaining pages.  The $500 goal will pay for about 5 pages, which isn't all of them, but as long as I can get some help paying for them, anything is good.

Stretch goals!

The first stretch goal is paying for the rest of the comic pages.  I'm so flat broke I can't afford the rest of them myself.

Second stretch goal:  Color!  Again, flat broke, so I can't afford to get the pages colored, but if we get enough money, I can afford to have the comic colored, and I do know people who would be capable of doing this, I just need to be able to pay them.

Third stretch goal:  Print?  A print version of this comic would be pretty fun, but by far the biggest expense, so we'd have to become way more successful than I've ever imagined.

Your support shows that people want more comics like this

We know we do.  Do you, too?

What you get

The comic, Literally #1, plain and simple.  Every backer, even for $1, gets a free link to the copy, either on a digital platform, or a PDF, or something like that.  Printing costs much more, and coloring the comic is still a stretch goal.

If you can't pay?

Spread this around on all the social media sites to let people know that we need everyone's help.
story_txt:
A comic about Helen Arambula, a 12 year old overweight girl in junior high school.  She's nerdy, she's homely to look at, she's kind of a mess, no one at school really likes her.

But when she gets home, she puts on her cosplay outfit, grabs a huge laser gun, and stands around in her bedroom, waiting to be teleported to an alien planet full of crazy monsters that she fights in her giant battle machine spraying lasers and missiles everywhere!
But does she actually teleport?  Will she wait in her bedroom the whole time, for the entire rest of the comic, just standing there?  Read the comic to find out!
Although no, she does teleport, it wouldn't be much of a comic otherwise.

Also you can't read the comic to find out yet, because I need the money to pay for the rest of the pages.  That's where we need your help!
We are Ran'Deesha Diaz (the writer) and Jacqueline Deglass (artist) and we've loved comics for many years, and we've finally decided to try making our own.
We want to make this comic because we think it would be a fun comic to read, for us and for anyone else.  Comics have a special advantage that no other medium has, because they can take the reader places that would take hundreds of millions of dollars for a movie or TV show to pull off, they can involve a reader visually in a way text can't, and they can go beyond the limits of imagination to do things no one thought of before, especially with characters no one's ever tried to make before.  We want to make comics like that!
Literally #1, what's it about?
It's a sort of bizarre satirical comedic action story that focuses on Helen Arambula, an overweight 12 year old Mexican girl who goes to an ordinary junior high school.  She seems like an average nerdy girl in school, but when she gets home, she puts on her cosplay outfit and teleports to another planet where endless swarms of monsters have to be fought back, and she joins a rag tag team of colorful diverse characters in fighting the monsters, while also balancing their normal daytime lives.  Helen's troubles are unique due to her situation, and how she interacts with her fellow mech jockeys leads to a lot of fun and exciting situations in combat.  And there's plenty of combat, with mechs stomping around and big crazy monsters attacking, and Helen is in the middle of all of it.
